stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on refining the UI and functionality for the new 'Egg Coin' radar system, which is part of a redesigned 7-star level structure. He iterated on the radar's visuals, fixed a critical spawning bug by uncovering a quirk in the M64 engine, and discussed the game's new overworld economy where coins are used for permanent world upgrades.

development_findings.summary: The game's structure has been changed to feature seven acts per course instead of six, with the seventh act dedicated to finding 'Egg Coins' and replacing the traditional 100-coin star.
A new coin radar, inspired by Sonic Adventure 1, has been implemented for the seventh act of each level to help players locate the Egg Coins.
development_findings.quote: It is very similar to that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is iterating on the radar's UI, experimenting with transparency effects to indicate proximity to a coin, making it more solid as the player gets closer.
Kaze solved a bug where dynamic lights weren't appearing by discovering a little-known feature of the original M64 engine that prevents objects from spawning if a specific parameter is set to 255.
development_findings.quote: There's a functionality in the Mario 64 engine where if you set the bparam3 to 255 the object does not spawn. This is so fucking wild.

development_findings.summary: Progress on levels was shared: Course 1 is nearly complete, Course 13 (Ice Castle) is 'basically done', Course 14 (Craft World) is 'mostly done', and Course 15 (Space Arcade) is in the very early stages.
Kaze is actively fixing bugs in preparation for a public demo which will feature Course 1.
A slide level featured in a previous project will not be returning in this game, though some of its art assets may be repurposed.
development_findings.quote: The slide as it was in This kind of a keg will not be returning.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is implementing a global coin system where players can spend collected coins on overworld upgrades, such as building a bridge, allowing players to tangibly alter the game world.
context_findings.quote: The coins are gonna be there to buy overworld upgrades. So like maybe there will be a guy that wants to build a bridge, but he needs a donation of 500 coins to buy the materials. So you give them the money and then the overworld changes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy prioritizes avoiding player frustration. He changed the coin radar from a purchasable item to a mandatory feature for the specific mission to prevent a poor user experience.
context_findings.quote: Imagine you have not bought the radar and you're doing mission 7 and the game doesn't give you any hint at all. That's gonna suck. That's gonna be a miserable experience.

context_findings.summary: When asked how long he's been coding, Kaze deflected, stating his focus is entirely on the game's development rather than his personal history or identity as a coder.
context_findings.quote: I think about game not about me. I want game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a pragmatic view on programming, stating that the choice of language is less important than the ability to accomplish the goal, and that C is sufficient for their needs.
context_findings.quote: Only bad programmers care about the programming language. C can already do everything we need.

context_findings.summary: Kaze tests the game on both Project64 for convenience and Parallel Launcher for compatibility, despite expressing frustration with Parallel Launcher's frequent updates.

biobak.summary: Biobak is creating assets for Course 1, specifically a 'line of mushrooms' that Kaze is waiting to implement.
Biobak joined the stream and Kaze immediately showed him the new coin radar for feedback, indicating a collaborative review process for new features.
Biobak asked about a 'Nintendo strike topic', showing he is aware of and possibly concerned with external factors and community discussions surrounding the project.

zeina.summary: Zeina was present during the stream.
Kaze tasked Zeina with a hardware-related errand: picking up a second N64 console, suggesting her support for the project extends to logistical and practical needs.

key_stories.title: Making the Radar User-Friendly
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified a potential design flaw where players could get stuck on a mission without a key item. He proactively changed the coin radar from a purchasable upgrade to a standard feature for that mission to prevent player frustration.
key_stories.challenge: The coin-finding radar was initially a purchasable item, which could lead to a frustrating experience for players who attempted the coin-finding mission without having bought it.
key_stories.process: Kaze considered the potential player journey and identified a major point of friction. He decided the negative potential outweighed the benefits of making the radar an optional purchase and redesigned the feature.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze made the radar an automatic, non-optional feature for the 7th mission in every level, prioritizing a smooth player experience over having an additional item in the game's economy.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine you have not bought the radar and you're doing a mission 7 and the game doesn't give you any hint at all. That's gonna suck. That's gonna be a miserable experience people are gonna hate that and I want to avoid that.

key_stories.title: The Invisible Lights Bug
key_stories.summary: While debugging, Kaze encountered invisible objects and, through investigation, uncovered a deep, obscure feature of the original Mario 64 engine. This moment highlights the technical archeology required when working with old codebases.
key_stories.challenge: Dynamic lights that were placed in a level were not spawning, and the reason was not immediately obvious.
key_stories.process: Kaze investigated the object's properties and behavior code, eventually discovering a niche, undocumented feature of the original Mario 64 engine that was causing the issue.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze identified that a specific object parameter (`bparam3`) being set to 255 was an engine-level instruction not to spawn the object. He fixed the issue by changing this value, demonstrating his deep knowledge of the underlying engine.
key_stories.key_quote: There's a functionality in the Mario 64 engine where if you set the bparam3 to 255 the object does not spawn. This is so fucking wild.

key_stories.title: Redefining the Purpose of Coins
key_stories.summary: Kaze revealed a major design pivot for the game's economy. Coins will no longer just be for earning stars but will be a currency used to fund projects that permanently alter the overworld, giving players a direct impact on the game's environment.
key_stories.challenge: How to make coin collecting feel meaningful and rewarding after removing the traditional 100-coin star.
key_stories.process: Kaze developed a new meta-game system that ties coin collection directly to world-building. Instead of being a per-level goal, coins contribute to a larger, persistent objective of improving and changing the game world.
key_stories.outcome: Coins are now planned as a global currency that players can use to fund projects in the overworld, such as building bridges. This makes collecting coins a core part of world progression and gives them tangible value.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe there will be a guy that wants to build a bridge but he needs a donation of 500 coins to buy the materials. So you give them the money and then the overworld changes. You're actually gonna affect the world by giving people money.

open_questions.context: Kaze explained that coins will be a global currency used to fund overworld projects, like donating 500 coins to an NPC to build a bridge.
questions: How extensive will this overworld upgrade system be? Are these upgrades optional side-quests or part of the critical path?
What was the process for balancing this economy? How do you determine the cost of upgrades like a bridge?
What other types of world-altering projects are you planning beyond building bridges?

open_questions.context: Kaze has changed the level structure from six stars plus a 100-coin star to a firm seven stars, with the seventh always being 'Find the Egg Coins'.
questions: What was the primary motivation for replacing the 100-coin star with a dedicated 'Egg Coin' act? What problem did this solve for you?
How does this structural change affect the gameplay loop and pacing of completing a course?
Was this a difficult decision to move away from the classic structure? Was there any debate among the team?

open_questions.context: Kaze spent much of the stream iterating on the coin radar's UI, trying different visual effects. He showed the work-in-progress to Biobak when he arrived.
questions: What is your process for finalizing a UI element that is both functional code and a key visual component? How do you balance your vision with feedback from the team and community?
To Biobak: What was your initial artistic feedback on the radar? How do you and Kaze collaborate to ensure new UI elements fit the game's overall aesthetic?

open_questions.topic: Level Theme Conception and Team Input
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that all main course themes are planned out (e.g., Ice Castle, Craft World) and that he was waiting on specific assets from Biobak.
questions: How did the team decide on the themes for the main courses? Was it a collaborative brainstorming process, or did you have a clear vision from the start?

To Biobak & Badub: How early are you brought into the design process for a new level? Do you create art and music based on a brief from Kaze, or does your creative work ever inspire the direction of a level?

open_questions.context: Zeina was present during the stream, and Kaze mentioned asking her to help with a practical task: acquiring a second N64 console.
questions: How do you two divide the labor on the project, balancing the creative work like animation with the practical, logistical needs of development?
How does your personal relationship as a married couple influence your professional collaboration, especially when it comes to giving and receiving creative feedback?
